# Target Date Funds

These are mutual funds that target a specific year for retirement. If the year is closer, the asset allocation will have more conservative strategies (more bonds over stocks). Bonds are loans to companies meaning companies have a legal obligation to pay you but the amount paid will be smaller than stocks. 

Target date funds also auto rebalances the asset allocation you have. So if the stock prices go up relative to bond prices, it will sell some stocks and buy some bonds to maintain the allocation percentages. Rebalancing forces you to sell high and buy low. 

Furthermore, target date funds will automatically adjust the allocation percentages as you age. If you are closer to retirement, it will adjust to a more conservative portfolio with more bonds than stocks.

There are two more alternatives to target date funds which will help with the above features: 1) Let financial advisor manage the fund 2) Let a robo advisor manage the fund. All choices will incur a fee because to pay the managers.

Fidelity target date funds offer the lowest expense ratio as of 2022.
